member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule
member.summary: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.AssertedControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AssertedControls.
The routing controls that are part of transactions that are evaluated to determine if a request to change a routing control state is allowed. For example, you might include three routing controls, one for each of three Amazon Web Services Regions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.ControlPanelArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlPanelArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the control panel.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
Name of the assertion rule. You can use any non-white space character in the name.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.RuleConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RuleConfig.
The criteria that you set for specific assertion controls (routing controls) that designate how many controls must be enabled as the result of a transaction. For example, if you have three assertion controls, you might specify atleast 2 for your rule configuration. This means that at least two assertion controls must be enabled, so that at least two Amazon Web Services Regions are enabled.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.SafetyRuleArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SafetyRuleArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the assertion rule.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The deployment status of an assertion rule. Status can be one of the following: PENDING, DEPLOYED, PENDING_DELETION.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRule.WaitPeriodMs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WaitPeriodMs.
An evaluation period, in milliseconds (ms), during which any request against the target routing controls will fail. This helps prevent "flapping" of state. The wait period is 5000 ms by default, but you can choose a custom value.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.AssertionRuleUpdate

The name of the assertion rule. You can use any non-white space character in the name.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.CreateClusterRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateCluster operation. Create a new cluster. A cluster is a set of redundant Regional endpoints against which you can run API calls to update or get the state of one or more routing controls. Each cluster has a name, status, Amazon Resource Name (ARN), and an array of the five cluster endpoints (one for each supported Amazon Web Services Region) that you can use with API calls to the Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller cluster data plane.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.CreateControlPanelRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateControlPanel operation. Creates a new control panel. A control panel represents a group of routing controls that can be changed together in a single transaction. You can use a control panel to centrally view the operational status of applications across your organization, and trigger multi-app failovers in a single transaction, for example, to fail over an Availability Zone or AWS Region.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.CreateSafetyRuleRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateSafetyRule operation. Creates a safety rule in a control panel. Safety rules let you add safeguards around enabling and disabling routing controls, to help prevent unexpected outcomes.
There are two types of safety rules: assertion rules and gating rules.
Assertion rule: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.
Gating rule: A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.

member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.GatingRule.TargetControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetControls.
Routing controls that can only be set or unset if the specified RuleConfig evaluates to true for the specified GatingControls. For example, say you have three gating controls, one for each of three Amazon Web Services Regions. Now you specify ATLEAST 2 as your RuleConfig. With these settings, you can only change (set or unset) the routing controls that you have specified as TargetControls if that rule evaluates to true.
In other words, your ability to change the routing controls that you have specified as TargetControls is gated by the rule that you set for the routing controls in GatingControls.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.GatingRule.WaitPeriodMs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WaitPeriodMs.
An evaluation period, in milliseconds (ms), during which any request against the target routing controls will fail. This helps prevent "flapping" of state. The wait period is 5000 ms by default, but you can choose a custom value.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule
member.summary: A new assertion rule for a control panel.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule.AssertedControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AssertedControls.
The routing controls that are part of transactions that are evaluated to determine if a request to change a routing control state is allowed. For example, you might include three routing controls, one for each of three Amazon Web Services Regions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule.ControlPanelArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlPanelArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the control panel.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the assertion rule. You can use any non-white space character in the name.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule.RuleConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RuleConfig.
The criteria that you set for specific assertion controls (routing controls) that designate how many controls must be enabled as the result of a transaction. For example, if you have three assertion controls, you might specify atleast 2 for your rule configuration. This means that at least two assertion controls must be enabled, so that at least two Amazon Web Services Regions are enabled.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewAssertionRule.WaitPeriodMs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WaitPeriodMs.
An evaluation period, in milliseconds (ms), during which any request against the target routing controls will fail. This helps prevent "flapping" of state. The wait period is 5000 ms by default, but you can choose a custom value.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule
member.summary: A new gating rule for a control panel.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.ControlPanelArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ControlPanelArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the control panel.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.GatingControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property GatingControls.
The gating controls for the new gating rule. That is, routing controls that are evaluated by the rule configuration that you specify.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name for the new gating rule.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.RuleConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RuleConfig.
The criteria that you set for specific gating controls (routing controls) that designates how many controls must be enabled to allow you to change (set or unset) the target controls.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.TargetControls
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetControls.
Routing controls that can only be set or unset if the specified RuleConfig evaluates to true for the specified GatingControls. For example, say you have three gating controls, one for each of three Amazon Web Services Regions. Now you specify AtLeast 2 as your RuleConfig. With these settings, you can only change (set or unset) the routing controls that you have specified as TargetControls if that rule evaluates to true.
In other words, your ability to change the routing controls that you have specified as TargetControls is gated by the rule that you set for the routing controls in GatingControls.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.NewGatingRule.WaitPeriodMs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WaitPeriodMs.
An evaluation period, in milliseconds (ms), during which any request against the target routing controls will fail. This helps prevent "flapping" of state. The wait period is 5000 ms by default, but you can choose a custom value.

member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.RoutingControl.Status
member.summary:

The deployment status of a routing control. Status can be one of the following: PENDING, DEPLOYED, PENDING_DELETION.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.Rule
member.summary: A safety rule. A safety rule can be an assertion rule or a gating rule.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.Rule.ASSERTION
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ASSERTION.
An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.Rule.GATING
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property GATING.
A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.

member.name: T:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.RuleConfig
member.summary: The rule configuration for an assertion rule. That is, the criteria that you set for specific assertion controls (routing controls) that specify how many controls must be enabled after a transaction completes.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.RuleConfig.Inverted
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Inverted.
Logical negation of the rule. If the rule would usually evaluate true, it's evaluated as false, and vice versa.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.RuleConfig.Threshold
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Threshold.
The value of N, when you specify an ATLEAST rule type. That is, Threshold is the number of controls that must be set when you specify an ATLEAST type.

member.name: P:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.RuleConfig.Type
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Type.
A rule can be one of the following: ATLEAST, AND, or OR.

member.summary: Create a new cluster. A cluster is a set of redundant Regional endpoints against which you can run API calls to update or get the state of one or more routing controls. Each cluster has a name, status, Amazon Resource Name (ARN), and an array of the five cluster endpoints (one for each supported Amazon Web Services Region) that you can use with API calls to the Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller cluster data plane.

member.summary:
Creates a new routing control.
A routing control has one of two states: ON and OFF. You can map the routing control state to the state of an Amazon Route 53 health check, which can be used to control traffic routing.
To get or update the routing control state, see the Recovery Cluster (data plane) API actions for Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller.

member.name: M:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.AmazonRoute53RecoveryControlConfigClient.CreateSafetyRule(Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.CreateSafetyRuleRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a safety rule in a control panel. Safety rules let you add safeguards around enabling and disabling routing controls, to help prevent unexpected outcomes.
There are two types of safety rules: assertion rules and gating rules.
Assertion rule: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.
Gating rule: A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateSafetyRule service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateSafetyRule service method, as returned by Route53RecoveryControlConfig.
member.exception: 500 response - InternalServiceError. Temporary service error. Retry the request.
400 response - Multiple causes. For example, you might have a malformed query string and input parameter might be out of range, or you used parameters together incorrectly.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateSafetyRule Operation

There are two types of safety rules: assertion rules and gating rules.
Assertion rule: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.
Gating rule: A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.

member.name: M:Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.IAmazonRoute53RecoveryControlConfig.CreateSafetyRule(Amazon.Route53RecoveryControlConfig.Model.CreateSafetyRuleRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a safety rule in a control panel. Safety rules let you add safeguards around enabling and disabling routing controls, to help prevent unexpected outcomes.
There are two types of safety rules: assertion rules and gating rules.
Assertion rule: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.
Gating rule: A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateSafetyRule service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateSafetyRule service method, as returned by Route53RecoveryControlConfig.
member.exception: 500 response - InternalServiceError. Temporary service error. Retry the request.
400 response - Multiple causes. For example, you might have a malformed query string and input parameter might be out of range, or you used parameters together incorrectly.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateSafetyRule Operation

Creates a safety rule in a control panel. Safety rules let you add safeguards around enabling and disabling routing controls, to help prevent unexpected outcomes.
There are two types of safety rules: assertion rules and gating rules.
Assertion rule: An assertion rule enforces that, when a routing control state is changed, the criteria set by the rule configuration is met. Otherwise, the change to the routing control is not accepted.
Gating rule: A gating rule verifies that a set of gating controls evaluates as true, based on a rule configuration that you specify. If the gating rule evaluates to true, Amazon Route 53 Application Recovery Controller allows a set of routing control state changes to run and complete against the set of target controls.
